algebra: branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and rules for manipulating those symbols
equation: a mathematical statement showing that two expressions are equal
variable: a letter or symbol used to represent an unknown value
coefficient: a number used to multiply a variable
exponent: a number that shows how many times to multiply a base number by itself
polynomial: an expression with variables and coefficients involving only addition, subtraction, and multiplication
quadratic: an equation containing a variable raised to the second power
factor: a number that divides exactly into another number
denominator: the bottom number in a fraction
numerator: the top number in a fraction
radius: the distance from the center to the edge of a circle
diameter: the distance across a circle through its center
perimeter: the distance around the outside of a shape
area: the amount of space inside a 2D shape
volume: the amount of space inside a 3D shape
parallel: lines that never meet and are always the same distance apart
perpendicular: lines that meet at a right angle (90 degrees)
hypotenuse: the longest side of a right triangle, opposite the right angle
pythagoras: theorem stating that a² + b² = c² in a right triangle
sine: ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle
cosine: ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle
tangent: ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent side in a right triangle
median: the middle value when data is arranged in order
mode: the most frequent value in a dataset
mean: the average found by adding all values and dividing by how many values there are
range: the difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset
probability: the likelihood of an event happening, expressed from 0 to 1
prime: a number with exactly two factors: 1 and itself
composite: a number with more than two factors
integer: a whole number that can be positive, negative, or zero
decimal: a number with a fractional part separated by a point
percentage: a number expressed as a fraction of 100
ratio: a comparison between two or more related numbers
proportion: an equation stating that two ratios are equal
sequence: a set of numbers that follow a pattern
arithmetic: a sequence where the difference between terms is constant
geometric: a sequence where each term is multiplied by a constant
gradient: the steepness of a line, calculated as rise over run
intercept: the point where a line crosses an axis
vertex: a corner point where two or more lines meet
angle: the amount of turn between two lines around their common point
isosceles: a triangle with two equal sides and two equal angles
equilateral: a triangle with all sides equal and all angles equal
scalene: a triangle with no equal sides and no equal angles
congruent: shapes that are exactly the same size and shape
similar: shapes that have the same shape but different sizes
symmetry: when a shape can be divided into identical parts
transformation: a way of changing the size or position of a shape
translation: moving a shape without rotating or flipping it
rotation: turning a shape around a fixed point
reflection: flipping a shape over a line
enlargement: making a shape bigger or smaller by a scale factor
vector: a quantity with both direction and magnitude
matrix: a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns
function: a rule that assigns exactly one output to each input
domain: the set of all possible input values of a function
range: the set of all possible output values of a function
inequality: a mathematical statement showing the relationship between unequal expressions
factorial: the product of all positive integers less than or equal to a number
reciprocal: one divided by a number (multiplicative inverse)
index: another word for exponent or power
surd: an expression involving square roots that cannot be simplified
irrational: a number that cannot be written as a simple fraction
rational: a number that can be written as a simple fraction
histogram: a graph showing continuous data using adjacent rectangles
frequency: how often something occurs in a dataset
correlation: a measure of the relationship between two variables
quartile: values that divide data into four equal parts
interquartile: the difference between the upper and lower quartiles
outlier: a value that differs significantly from other data points
discrete: data that can only take certain values
continuous: data that can take any value within a range
linear: relating to a straight line or first degree equation
polygon: a closed shape with straight sides
cylinder: a 3D shape with circular ends and straight sides
cone: a 3D shape with a circular base and a pointed top
prism: a 3D shape with identical ends and flat faces
pyramid: a 3D shape with a polygon base and triangular faces meeting at a point
